key_insight: An LLM-based planning agent (SAGE) with human-in-the-loop chain-of-thought reasoning can feasibly automate stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) planning while providing interpretable, auditable decision traces that address black‑box concerns.
problem_solved: SRS planning requires highly precise dose shaping around critical brain structures, but opaque black‑box AI tools hinder clinical adoption due to lack of interpretability and clinician trust.
method: Developed SAGE (Secure Agent for Generative Dose Expertise), an LLM-driven treatment‑planning agent with two variants (including a chain‑of‑thought enabled variant) to generate SRS plans.
Integrated human‑in‑the‑loop review and audit trails to allow clinicians to inspect and override planning decisions.
Retrospectively evaluated feasibility on a cohort of 41 brain metastasis patients treated with single‑fraction 18 Gy SRS to compare plan plausibility, safety checks, and interpretability.
impact: Provides a practical pathway for integrating LLMs into high‑stakes clinical workflows by prioritizing explainability and clinician oversight; this can accelerate safe adoption of AI planning tools and guide future work on agentic medical AI.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram of SAGE showing inputs (imaging, contours), LLM reasoning (chain‑of‑thought), human review, and final plan export
Side‑by‑side plan visualization (dose overlay on MRI) comparing conventional plan vs. SAGE output
Flowchart or annotated example of the agent's chain‑of‑thought reasoning trace for a sample decision (e.g., OAR sparing vs. target coverage)
Bar/box plots summarizing retrospective cohort metrics (e.g., pass/fail safety checks, plan acceptability rates) to illustrate feasibility
paper_title: Automated stereotactic radiosurgery planning using a human-in-the-loop reasoning large language model agent
paper_authors: Humza Nusrat, Luke Francisco, Bing Luo, Hassan Bagher-Ebadian, Joshua Kim
